section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: The student should be able to:
specific_objectives: The student should be able to:

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 1. describe the major functions of the family;
content: The major functions of the family: (a) as a unit of procreation; (b) as a social unit for rearing children, namely, the socialisation of the individual; (c) as an economic unit for satisfying basic needs: (i) budgeting; (ii) finance and availability of credit;
specific_objectives: describe the major functions of the family
content_items: The major functions of the family: (a) as a unit of procreation
(b) as a social unit for rearing children
(c) as an economic unit for satisfying basic needs: (i) budgeting

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 2. evaluate different sources to determine a definition o(fa )t he family;
content: (a) Evaluation Criteria: (i) accuracy; (ii) authority; (iii) currency; (iv) objectivity; (v) coverage; and, (vi) relevance. (b) Definitions of the Family.
specific_objectives: evaluate different sources to determine a definition o(fa )t he family

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 3a. examine different family types, relations, unions and forms of marriage in the Caribbean and the wider world; 3b. *demonstrate respect and tolerance of others from different family types and unions;
content: Family types, relations, unions and forms of marriage in the Caribbean and the wider world: Types – nuclear, extended, sibling households, single parent family; Relations – Family Tree (illustrate and interpret); Unions (legal and civil) – visiting relationships, consensual or common law, marriage; and, Examination of the traditional and modern forms of marriage in the wider world.
specific_objectives: forms of marriage in the Caribbean
tolerance of others from different family types
content_items: forms of marriage in the Caribbean
modern forms of marriage in the wider world.

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 4. examine the roles and responsibilities of adults and children of a Caribbean family;
content: Traditional versus Contemporary roles and responsibilities.

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 5a. examine the causes and effects of the changes in the roles and responsibilities of family members in Caribbean society;
content: Factors which contribute to the changing roles and responsibilities of women, men and children in the Caribbean family. For example: (a) status and increased rights of women in society; (b) choice of employment; (c) available technology; (d) societal values/pressure; (e) leisure activities; and, (f) educational opportunities. Results of the changing roles and responsibilities of women, men and children in the Caribbean family. For example: (a) Role conflict; (b) Identity crisis; (c) Breakdown in communication; (d) Marginalization of males; (e) Challenges of gender equality; (f) Independence of family members; and, (g) Shared responsibilities.
specific_objectives: effects of the changes in the roles
responsibilities of family members in Caribbean society
content_items: Factors which contribute to the changing roles
children in the Caribbean family. For example: (a) status
increased rights of women in society
(f) educational opportunities. Results of the changing roles
children in the Caribbean family. For example: (a) Role conflict

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 5b. *formulate questions to guide information search;
content: Qualities of a good research question: (a) feasible with given time; (b) researchable – requires more than yes or no to answer; and, (c) specific- variables are clearly stated.
content_items: Qualities of a good research question: (a) feasible with given time

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 6. examine factors which assist in the preparation for parenthood;
content: Preparation for parenthood – physical, economic, emotional and psychological readiness.
specific_objectives: examine factors which assist in the preparation for parenthood

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 7. *design simple questionnaires to gather information about the family;
specific_objectives: *design simple questionnaires to gather information about the family

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 8. examine the qualities of an effective parent;
content: Qualities of an effective parent: Problem solving skills, communication skills, socialising skills, disciplinary skills, knowledge of good nutrition, showing of love/warmth, good money management, decision-making skills.
specific_objectives: examine the qualities of an effective parent
content_items: Qualities of an effective parent: Problem solving skills

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 9a. examine causes and effects of contemporary social issues that influence and affect persons in Caribbean family life;
content: Vulnerable persons include persons living with disabilities, children, elderly, mentally ill, persons with special needs and the LGBTQ+ community. Causes and effects of contemporary social issues which influence persons in Caribbean family life such as: teenage pregnancy, child abandonment, sibling rivalry, divorce and separation, generation gap, substance abuse, juvenile delinquency, sexually transmitted diseases, child abuse, poverty, desertion, suicide, incest, domestic violence, trafficking in persons, abuse and neglect of the elderly, mentally ill and those with special needs. Note to Teacher: The causes and effects of the social issues are inter-related and should be presented in that manner.
specific_objectives: effects of contemporary social issues that influence
affect persons in Caribbean family life
content_items: Vulnerable persons include persons living with disabilities
effects of contemporary social issues which influence persons in Caribbean family life such as: teenage pregnancy
those with special needs. Note to Teacher: The causes
effects of the social issues are inter-related
should be presented in that manner.

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 9b. propose solutions to problems faced by the family;
content: Solution/s should identify a particular strategy, resources needed; should be feasible. Feasibility should be supported by evidence/arguments.
specific_objectives: 9b. propose solutions to problems faced by the family
content_items: Solution/s should identify a particular strategy
should be feasible. Feasibility should be supported by evidence/arguments.

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 9c. justify solutions to contemporary social issues that influence Caribbean family life;
content: Solutions to contemporary social issues (listed in SO 9a) which influence Caribbean family life such as: (a) education and training; (b) financial support; (c) increased employment opportunities; (d) counselling; (e) law enforcement; (f) social services and institutions; and; (g) family support.
specific_objectives: 9c. justify solutions to contemporary social issues that influence Caribbean family life
content_items: Solutions to contemporary social issues (listed in SO 9a) which influence Caribbean family life such as: (a) education

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 9d. *design interview schedules to gather information about issues which affect the family;
content: Guidelines for designing Interview Schedules: (a) use open-ended questions (allowing for further questions/probing); (b) sequence questions from general to specific; and, (c) use simple, short questions that do not have multiple parts.
specific_objectives: 9d. *design interview schedules to gather information about issues which affect the family
content_items: Guidelines for designing Interview Schedules: (a) use open-ended questions (allowing for further questions/probing)
(b) sequence questions from general to specific
short questions that do not have multiple parts.

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 10. describe the laws to protect the family in social situations as listed in content (9a);
content: Laws related to: (a) inheritance; (b) child care; (c) legal separation; (d) divorce; and, (e) domestic violence.
specific_objectives: describe the laws to protect the family in social situations as listed in content (9a)

objective: 11. account for the cultural diversity of the Caribbean region;

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 12. evaluate the ways in which cultural heritage in the Caribbean is transmitted and transformed;
content: Transfer of cultural heritage through communication by: (a) Agents of Transmission (i) family; (ii) cultural groups; (iii) artists; (iv) mass media (including social media); and, (v) institutions. (b) Transformations (i) customs/festivals/celebrations; (ii) cultural exchanges among the various ethnic groups (creolization); and, (iii) commercialisation.
specific_objectives: evaluate the ways in which cultural heritage in the Caribbean is transmitted
content_items: Transfer of cultural heritage through communication by: (a) Agents of Transmission (i) family
(ii) cultural exchanges among the various ethnic groups (creolization)

objective: 13. evaluate the impact of the Caribbean cultural forms on the global stage;

content: Relationship between citizen and government as stated in the constitution. (a) Definition of the following terms and concepts: constitution, democracy, authoritarian. (b) Human rights, freedoms and responsibilities. (c) Right to vote (adult suffrage). (d) Role of the Ombudsman and other regulatory authorities.

responsibilities. (c) Right to vote (adult suffrage). (d) Role of the Ombudsman

objective: 24. describe the systems used to elect a government in the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: (a) Electoral processes (i) Dissolution of parliament (announcement date for election); (ii) Role of Elections Commission/Electoral Office; (iii) Independent Observer Mission (regional and international); (iv) Role of political parties;
specific_objectives: describe the systems used to elect a government in the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: (a) Electoral processes (i) Dissolution of parliament (announcement date for election)

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 25a. evaluate how political parties prepare for elections;
content: Preparation for elections: (a) establish the party structure (for example, chairpersons/secretaries/executives constituency branches); (b) select candidates; (c) source campaign financing; (d) conduct campaigns using different forms of communication. For example: (i) Face-to-face; (ii) Flyers; (iii) ICT; (iv) Media; and, (iv) Political rallies. (e) monitor the electoral processes; (f) commission public opinion polls; and, (g) develop the manifesto.

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 29. identify the characteristics (oif) good governance; and,
content: Characteristics of good governance – participation/inclusiveness, independence of the judiciary, transparency, accountability, responsiveness to the needs of citizens, service of the greater good of citizens, prudent use of resources, efficient civil service, willingness to engage in consultation, tolerance of freedom of expression, creative and innovative.
content_items: responsiveness to the needs of citizens
service of the greater good of citizens

section: SECTION A: INDIVIDUAL
objective: 30. identify the characteristics of good citizenship.
content: Civic duties such as: Active participation, respect for human rights, law abiding, environmentally conscious, well informed, embrace healthy lifestyle practices, show concern for others, productive citizens, patriotic.
specific_objectives: identify the characteristics of good citizenship.
content_items: Civic duties such as: Active participation

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 1. describe the characteristics of a population;
content: Characteristics of a population according to age and sex structure, occupation, ethnicity, religion, dependency ratio, life expectancy, mortality rates, size, density, spatial distribution, birth rates, health, education, income level and employment status.
specific_objectives: describe the characteristics of a population
content_items: Characteristics of a population according to age

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 2a. identify the sources and uses of population statistics;
content: Sources of population statistics - Government Statistical Offices/websites – National Census, Registrar of Births Deaths, and Marriages, records of religious institutions, Immigration and Customs. Uses of population statistics - For current and future planning related to: elections, housing, health care, education, employment, social welfare, infrastructural and industrial development, population control, sustainable development and management of resources.
content_items: Sources of population statistics - Government Statistical Offices/websites – National Census
Customs. Uses of population statistics - For current

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 3a. examine the factors influencing population distribution and density;
content: Factors influencing population distribution and density: (a) Physical factors: the relief, climate, soils, vegetation, location of natural resources – water, fertile land, minerals. (b) Human factors: Industry, agriculture, accessibility to transport, infrastructure – (roads, electricity) and social services. Impact of under and over population on a country’s development.
specific_objectives: 3a. examine the factors influencing population distribution
content_items: over population on a country’s development.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 3b. interpret maps showing population distribution and density;
content: Choropleth and dot maps. Map reading skills: (a) Title; (b) North arrow; (c) Key/legend; (d) Scale; and, (e) Border. Note the importance of neatness.
content_items: dot maps. Map reading skills: (a) Title
(e) Border. Note the importance of neatness.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4a. explain how different factors influence population change;
content: Factors influencing population change: birth rate, death rate, migration. Birth rate, fertility rate, infant mortality, life expectancy and death (mortality) rate: (a) healthcare, nutrition, hygiene, access to family planning methods, governmental policies, income and education levels, epidemics, pandemics and natural disasters. Migration: Net migration (immigration minus emigration): (a) internal migration (rural-urban, urban- rural);
specific_objectives: 4a. explain how different factors influence population change
content_items: Factors influencing population change: birth rate
natural disasters. Migration: Net migration (immigration minus emigration): (a) internal migration (rural-urban

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4b. calculate demographic rates;
content: (a) birth rate; (b) death rate; (c) rate of natural increase; (d) overall population growth; and, (e) net migration.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4c. select an appropriate statistical diagram to represent a data set;
content: Statistical diagrams such as: line and bar graphs, pie charts, population pyramid. Considerations for selecting the most suitable representation: (a) line graph – time and series data; (b) bar graph – discrete categories; (c) pie chart – percentage showing how the total data is distributed;
specific_objectives: 4c. select an appropriate statistical diagram to represent a data set
content_items: population pyramid. Considerations for selecting the most suitable representation: (a) line graph – time
(c) pie chart – percentage showing how the total data is distributed

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4d. represent data related to human resources;
content: Data related to human resources: population, migration, employment and unemployment statistics. Population pyramids, line graphs, pie charts, bar graphs and tables.
specific_objectives: 4d. represent data related to human resources
content_items: Data related to human resources: population

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4e. interpret data related to human resources;
content: Interpretation of tables, construction and use of line and bar graphs, pie charts, population pyramids.
specific_objectives: 4e. interpret data related to human resources

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 5. *integrate information from a variety of sources to make informed conclusions;
content: Ensuring validity/reliability of information, analyse information, synthesise, draw conclusions.
specific_objectives: *integrate information from a variety of sources to make informed conclusions

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 6a. examine the causes and consequences of migration;
content: Migration: (a) Causes: (i) Push and pull factors that influence migration. For example, economic, government policies, social factors, educational opportunities, over and under population, conflict and natural disasters. (b) Consequences of migration to the individual, the host country and to the country of origin. For example, brain drain, educational advancement, depopulation, bigotry, urbanisation, remittances, cultural diversity, employment, unemployment and under- employment, over and under population.
content_items: pull factors that influence migration. For example
natural disasters. (b) Consequences of migration to the individual
to the country of origin. For example

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 6b. examine the reasons for migration from Caribbean countries;
content: Reasons for migration from the Caribbean to Panama, UK, USA and Canada such as: (a) Employment; (b) Natural disaster; (c) Education; (d) Social Services/Medical treatment; and, (e) Asylum (political, economic, safety and security).
specific_objectives: 6b. examine the reasons for migration from Caribbean countries
content_items: Reasons for migration from the Caribbean to Panama

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 7. examine the global impact of migration from the Caribbean;
content: Impact of migration from the Caribbean on the host countries: (a) Economy; (b) Spread of Caribbean culture; (c) Increased presence and influence in the global sphere (lobbying for Caribbean interest); and, (d) Social services.
specific_objectives: examine the global impact of migration from the Caribbean
content_items: Impact of migration from the Caribbean on the host countries: (a) Economy
influence in the global sphere (lobbying for Caribbean interest)

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 8. explain the need for developing human resources;
content: The need for: Productive workers, creative and critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
specific_objectives: explain the need for developing human resources

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 9. explain the factors that contribute to the development of human resources;
content: Development of human resources through: (a) nutrition and health; (b) the availability of and access to primary and curative health care; (c) education (basic, moral, vocational, technical and professional training, rehabilitation, retraining, life-long learning); (d) the availability and access to various types of educational institutions; (e) the availability of financial resource/provision of scholarships; (f) sports; and, (g) culture. Technology – its impact on access to teaching and learning opportunities.
specific_objectives: explain the factors that contribute to the development of human resources
content_items: Development of human resources through: (a) nutrition
access to various types of educational institutions
(e) the availability of financial resource/provision of scholarships
(g) culture. Technology – its impact on access to teaching

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 10. explain the factors that influence employment, unemployment and underemployment;
content: Factors that influence employment, unemployment and under- employment: (a) availability and use of capital; (b) availability of trained human resource; (c) level and range of skills demanded versus those available; (d) availability and creation of markets, trading patterns and preferences; (e) level of technology available in relation to resource development and technological advances; (f) economic downturn/recession; (g) gender and employment; and, (h) entrepreneurial interests/ opportunities.
specific_objectives: explain the factors that influence employment
content_items: range of skills demanded versus those available
(e) level of technology available in relation to resource development

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 11. outline employment and career opportunities in different industries;
content: Careers and Opportunities in the four industries: (a) Primary Industry (i) Agriculture, Fishing and Mining. (b) Secondary Industry (i) Manufacturing and Construction. (c) Tertiary Industry (i) Tourism and other services. (d) Quaternary Industry (i) Knowledge industry – information technology, research and development.
content_items: Opportunities in the four industries: (a) Primary Industry (i) Agriculture
other services. (d) Quaternary Industry (i) Knowledge industry – information technology

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 12a. identify the location of the major natural resources in the Caribbean;

objective: 12b. describe the uses of the major natural resources found in the Caribbean region;
content: Uses of resources (a) Agricultural land: Importance – to the region / countries. (b) Land and marine life: Importance and use. (c) Forests: Importance and use. Uses of major forestry resources in the region (Guyana, Belize). (d) Mineral resources: Bauxite, petroleum, geothermal energy.
specific_objectives: 12b. describe the uses of the major natural resources found in the Caribbean region
content_items: Uses of resources (a) Agricultural land: Importance – to the region / countries. (b) Land

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 13. examine the effects of proper and improper practices on the environment and the population;
content: (a) Sustainable development (Proper) practices, for example, conservation – reforestation, contour ploughing, terracing, crop rotation, controlled logging, zoning, reserve. (b) Improper practices, for example, actions by farmers that lead to soil degradation/erosion, over-cropping, monocropping, ploughing up and down slopes, removal of vegetation, improper tillage, deforestation, poor housing development, individual, industry and community practices. (c) Effects of proper practices, for example, food security. (d) Effects of improper practices, for example, soil erosion, mass wasting, pollution, global warming, food shortages, deforestation.
content_items: actions by farmers that lead to soil degradation/erosion
community practices. (c) Effects of proper practices
food security. (d) Effects of improper practices

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 14. explain the causes and consequences of climate change;
content: (a) Global warming – causes and consequences. (b) Climate change – causes and consequences: (i) Causes: natural and anthropogenic (man-made); and, (ii) Consequences: sea-level rise, extreme climate variability, droughts and floods, stronger hurricanes, destruction of coral reefs and other marine resources, negative impacts on health.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 15. evaluate the responses to climate change;
content: Responses: (a) Actions by individuals/ communities/organisations for living sustainably. For example, Reduce, Reuse and Recycle, greater use of public transportation, carpooling, reduction in air transport, use of biodegradable materials, use of alternate energy supplies. (b) Government responses/strategies: policy, laws, regulations. For example, planning/zoning, building codes, disaster preparedness, education, law enforcement, reduction in the use of fossil fuel, reduction in CFCs and Greenhouse gases.
specific_objectives: evaluate the responses to climate change
content_items: Responses: (a) Actions by individuals/ communities/organisations for living sustainably. For example
use of alternate energy supplies. (b) Government responses/strategies: policy
reduction in the use of fossil fuel

objective: 19. locate the Caribbean region in relation to the rest of the world;

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 20. identify different groupings of territories within the Caribbean;
content: Caribbean divisions – Groupings: Greater and Lesser Antilles, Leewards and Windwards. Eastern Caribbean, Mainland territories – Guyana, Suriname, Belize.
specific_objectives: identify different groupings of territories within the Caribbean

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 21. explain the use of the various ways of measuring development;
content: (a) Definition of development. (b) Ways of Measuring Development: (i) Economic: - Gross Domestic Product/Gross National Product; - Per capita income; and, - Cost of living. (ii) Social: - Education; - Literacy rate; - Life expectancy; - Infant mortality rate; and, - Availability of social services. (iii) Human Development Index (HDI). (c) Uses of the above indicators of development.
specific_objectives: explain the use of the various ways of measuring development
content_items: (a) Definition of development. (b) Ways of Measuring Development: (i) Economic: - Gross Domestic Product/Gross National Product
Availability of social services. (iii) Human Development Index (HDI). (c) Uses of the above indicators of development.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 22. assess the factors that influence the development of various industries and the contribution of these industries to the economic development in the Caribbean;
content: Factors that influence development of various industries. For example, Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing, Mining, Tourism and other services, Manufacturing, Cultural/Creative: (a) Investment; (b) Markets; (c) Infrastructural development; (d) Policy and regulations; (e) Technology; and, (f) Education/skills of workers. Contributions of various industries, for example, Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing, Mining, Tourism and other services, Manufacturing, Cultural/Creative to: (a) foreign exchange earnings and savings/ income; (b) direct employment, such as hotel workers, farm managers, engineers, artists and artistes; (c) indirect employment through linkages with other sectors of the economy (for example, agriculture, tourism, arts and craft, transportation and other ancillary services); and, (d) government revenue (taxes, licenses).
specific_objectives: assess the factors that influence the development of various industries
the contribution of these industries to the economic development in the Caribbean
content_items: Factors that influence development of various industries. For example
(f) Education/skills of workers. Contributions of various industries
(c) indirect employment through linkages with other sectors of the economy (for example

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 23. describe how information and communication technology impacts industries in the Caribbean;
content: Impact of information and communication technology on industries: (a) greater efficiency; (b) access to wider market; (c) greater accessibility; (d) easier access to financial services; (e) reduced business cost; (f) improvement in research and development; (g) facilitates entrepreneurship; and, (h) increases access to education for workers
specific_objectives: communication technology impacts industries in the Caribbean
content_items: communication technology on industries: (a) greater efficiency
(h) increases access to education for workers

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 24a. discuss the major challenges facing development in the Caribbean region;
content: Major challenges: Physical: (a) distinction between hazard and disaster; (b) vulnerability to natural hazards/disasters: (i) hurricanes, floods, drought, earthquakes, volcanoes and tsunamis; and, (ii) causes (natural and anthropogenic) and effects. (c) disaster management/resilience.
specific_objectives: 24a. discuss the major challenges facing development in the Caribbean region
content_items: Major challenges: Physical: (a) distinction between hazard

section: SECTION B: SUSAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 24b. propose strategies to mitigate challenges faced by the Caribbean region;
content: Useful skills such as: Research, discussion, creativity.
specific_objectives: 24b. propose strategies to mitigate challenges faced by the Caribbean region

section: SECTION B: SUSAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 24c. justify strategies proposed to mitigate challenges faced by the Caribbean;
content: Useful skills such as: Research, discussion, creativity, oral and written communication.
specific_objectives: 24c. justify strategies proposed to mitigate challenges faced by the Caribbean

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 25. examine the factors that promote regional integration;
content: Factors promoting regional integration: (a) geographical location; (b) common cultural heritage; (c) common economic and social issues; (d) effects of globalisation, trade liberalisation and trading blocs; (e) vulnerability to economic shocks, climate change and natural disasters; (f) advancements in communication technologies that facilitate the transfer of cultural heritage, for example, Social Media; and, (g) Consumer practices in the region: (i) awareness of integration objectives; (ii) preference for local and regional goods and services; and, (iii) investment in local and regional businesses.
specific_objectives: examine the factors that promote regional integration
content_items: Factors promoting regional integration: (a) geographical location
(f) advancements in communication technologies that facilitate the transfer of cultural heritage
(g) Consumer practices in the region: (i) awareness of integration objectives

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 26. outline the major attempts at regional integration;
content: (a) Types of agreements between countries and states: (i) Bi-lateral agreements; and, (ii) Multilateral agreements. (b) Attempts: (i) West Indies Federation; (ii) Caribbean Free Trade Association (CARIFTA); (iii) Caribbean Community (CARICOM); (iv) Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS); (v) Association of Caribbean States (ACS); and, (vi) The CARICOM Single Market and Economy (CSME): common market, single market, single economy, economic integration.
specific_objectives: outline the major attempts at regional integration
content_items: (ii) Multilateral agreements. (b) Attempts: (i) West Indies Federation

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 28. analyse the benefits and successes of regional integration;
content: Benefits of regional integration: (a) reduction in unemployment and underemployment; (b) better response to economic implications of globalisation and trade liberalisation; (c) improvement in the quality of life; (d) reduction in the inequality of wealth distribution; (e) free movement of goods, labour and capital; (f) increased market size; (g) improved levels of international competitiveness; (h) expansion of trade; (i) increased co-operation among member states – regionalism; and, (j) Greater international presence.
content_items: Benefits of regional integration: (a) reduction in unemployment
(b) better response to economic implications of globalisation
(c) improvement in the quality of life
(d) reduction in the inequality of wealth distribution
(i) increased co-operation among member states – regionalism

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 29. examine the factors that hinder the attempts at regional integration;
content: Factors that hinder regional integration: (a) geography of region; (b) absence of common model or strategy for development; (c) differences in stages of growth and development; (d) competition for foreign investment; (e) conflict between territorial and regional demands and loyalties; (f) insularities; (g) political will; (h) lack of/high cost of interregional transport; (i) absence of common currency; (j) unequal distribution of resources; (k) lack of diversification in production; and, (l) influence of multinational corporations. Note to teacher: refer to attempts at integration that have failed in the region.
specific_objectives: examine the factors that hinder the attempts at regional integration
content_items: Factors that hinder regional integration: (a) geography of region
(h) lack of/high cost of interregional transport
(l) influence of multinational corporations. Note to teacher: refer to attempts at integration that have failed in the region.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 30. examine the role of individual citizens, business organisations, government and the mass media in the integration process;
content: (a) Role of citizens: For example: (i) entrepreneurship; (ii) supporting regional producers, institutions; (iii) showing solidarity and mutual support towards fellow regional citizens; a collective consciousness (shared ideas and attitudes operating as a unifying force); (iv) investing in local and regional businesses; and, (v) being informed. (b) Role of business organisations: For example: (i) improving competitiveness; (ii) increasing range and quality of goods and services; and, (iii) providing opportunities for investment and employment.
specific_objectives: examine the role of individual citizens
the mass media in the integration process
content_items: (a) Role of citizens: For example: (i) entrepreneurship
mutual support towards fellow regional citizens
attitudes operating as a unifying force)
(v) being informed. (b) Role of business organisations: For example: (i) improving competitiveness

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 31. describe ways in which tourism can be used to promote regional integration; and,
content: Promoting regional cooperation and integration through tourism by: (a) marketing the Caribbean as a single destination; (b) recognition of the tourism products packaged by each Caribbean country; (eco or nature, health, sports, cultural or heritage, music festivals, special events); (c) common economic and marketing policies; (d) creating linkages within Caribbean – (communication); and, (e) concept of aviation hubs.
specific_objectives: describe ways in which tourism can be used to promote regional integration
content_items: integration through tourism by: (a) marketing the Caribbean as a single destination
(b) recognition of the tourism products packaged by each Caribbean country

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 32. differentiate between the types of tourism products available in the Caribbean.
content: Types of tourism products: sand, sea, sun, nature or eco, health, sports, cultural or heritage, music festivals, special events.
specific_objectives: differentiate between the types of tourism products available in the Caribbean.

objective: 6. Analysis and Interpretation of Data • Relevant to the research questions and well developed • Relevant to the research questions but not well developed • Adequate supporting data • Limited supporting data • Relevant generalisations/ linkages/ connections/ comparisons based on data • Data given with limited generalisations/ linkages/ connections/ comparisons • Reference to at least two sources • Reference to fewer than two sources

section:
SECTION B
Answer BOTH questions in this section
objective: 1. Parent mentorship - support programmes can be established through the church or the school where parents can partner with each other to give support. 2. Parents who go before the family courts should be ordered to participate in mandatory parenting classes. 3. School counsellors can hold parenting sessions for the parent body at their school.
content: 1. In the mentorship or support programmes, parents can learn from each other’s experiences. They can share ideas on parenting and provide guidance for their children. 2. The court ordering parenting classes will force parents who need it, to attend these classes. These classes will provide them knowledge, skills and tools to be able to give their children proper guidance. 3.Since school is compulsory for children 5-16 years, this facilitates access to many parents all over the country. Through parents’ meetings and in one-on-one sessions, school counsellors have an opportunity to advise parents on how they can properly guide their children.
specific_objectives: Parent mentorship - support programmes can be established through the church

the school where parents can partner with each other to give support. 2. Parents who go before the family courts should be ordered to participate in mandatory parenting classes. 3. School counsellors can hold parenting sessions for the parent body at their school.

tools to be able to give their children proper guidance. 3.Since school is compulsory for children 5-16 years
this facilitates access to many parents all over the country. Through parents’ meetings
school counsellors have an opportunity to advise parents on how they can properly guide their children.

section:

objective: 4. Parenting programmes that provide tips for parents could be aired via television, radio and social media. 5. The private and corporate sector can establish programmes to provide assistance to parents who need guidance with raising their children.
content: 4.Throughout the country parents have access to a variety of media. If all media platforms have programmes where experts, professionals and parents share tips and advice for parents, this will reach a wide audience and improve parental guidance. 5. Many parents can be reached through their workplaces. If all private and corporate sector agencies provide parenting classes or information for staff, then a large percentage of the public will be able to receive the help they need to guide their children.

corporate sector can establish programmes to provide assistance to parents who need guidance with raising their children.

section:

objective: 6. Government agencies such social services can provide resources such as brochures and other information to parents showing them ways to provide appropriate guidance for their children.
content: 6.In many countries parents who are having difficulty with their children may visit social agencies such as child and human services and social welfare programmes. These agencies, therefore, have direct contact with parents who need guidance. Having information on providing guidance for children in these offices ensures that the persons who need the assistance have access to this information.

section:
SECTION B
Answer BOTH questions in this section
objective: 1. The Ministry of Education can ensure that the importance of participation in the electoral process is part of the school curriculum at all levels. 2. Through the electoral offices, governments can have an education campaign in the various schools to inform students about the importance of voting. 3. Government can enlist the help of popular social media influencers to use their platform to encourage young people to vote in elections.
content: 1.If this topic is included in the school curriculum, many students who will one day become registered voters, will be taught, and hopefully understand, the importance of participating in elections. This will encourage them to vote when the time comes. 2. This strategy will be successful because students in all schools throughout the country will be informed, not only about the voting process, but more importantly the importance of voting. This will encourage them to participate when they become of age to vote. 3. Young persons spend a lot of time on social media and are influenced by popular individuals on social media. If these persons are enlisted in a social media campaign to highlight the need to vote, they can influence their followers to do the same.
specific_objectives: The Ministry of Education can ensure that the importance of participation in the electoral process is part of the school curriculum at all levels. 2. Through the electoral offices

governments can have an education campaign in the various schools to inform students about the importance of voting. 3. Government can enlist the help of popular social media influencers to use their platform to encourage young people to vote in elections.

many students who will one day become registered voters

the importance of participating in elections. This will encourage them to vote when the time comes. 2. This strategy will be successful because students in all schools throughout the country will be informed

are influenced by popular individuals on social media. If these persons are enlisted in a social media campaign to highlight the need to vote
they can influence their followers to do the same.

section:

objective: 4. Government can organize musical concerts with popular artistes geared at influencing young persons to register and go out to vote in elections.
content: 4.Young persons love music and having a good time. Using music and popular artistes as tools to facilitate educating them on the topic of voting, will ensure that the message will most likely reach many of them.

go out to vote in elections.

section:
SECTION B
Answer BOTH questions in this section
objective: 1. Provide/develop employment especially in areas that require higher education, skills and so on. 2. Expand/develop opportunities for higher- level education and training at tertiary level. 3. Improve the standard of living by providing increased and improved social services, infrastructure, educational facilities etc. 4. Encourage the provision of higher salaries/wages and better working conditions.
content: 1. This would encourage persons to remain in the country rather than migrate, since they would be able to find employment commensurate with their level of skill /training/education. 2. This may encourage persons to remain at home rather than go abroad in search of such educational opportunities. 3. Persons are less likely to migrate where there is a high standard of living and where social services are provided at a high level. 4. Persons are less likely to emigrate where wages are high or at acceptable levels and where working conditions and benefits are good.

section:
SECTION B
Answer BOTH questions in this section
objective: 3. Allocate more resources to protecting coastlines from rising sea levels. This could include the building of protective barriers and boardwalks, and revegetating the coastlines. 4. Protect and replant coastal vegetation. 5. Establish marine reserves and laws to protect coral reefs and other marine organisms.
content: 3. Improved protection of coastlines would help to reduce the damage caused by rising sea levels. Barriers would help to shield the coastline by absorbing and deflecting some of the energy of the waves. 4.Protecting and replanting coastal vegetation would reduce the impact of rising sea levels since the roots and body of the vegetation help to anchor and protect the soil and sand from erosion. 5.Coral reefs help to protect the coastline from wave attack by absorbing and deflecting the power of waves. They also provide material for beaches which also help to protect the land from wave attack.
specific_objectives: Allocate more resources to protecting coastlines from rising sea levels. This could include the building of protective barriers
replant coastal vegetation. 5. Establish marine reserves
content_items: Improved protection of coastlines would help to reduce the damage caused by rising sea levels. Barriers would help to shield the coastline by absorbing
deflecting some of the energy of the waves. 4.Protecting
replanting coastal vegetation would reduce the impact of rising sea levels since the roots
body of the vegetation help to anchor
sand from erosion. 5.Coral reefs help to protect the coastline from wave attack by absorbing
deflecting the power of waves. They also provide material for beaches which also help to protect the land from wave attack.

section:
SECTION B
Answer BOTH questions in this section
objective: 6. Encourage the development of settlements and industries away from the coastlines.
content: 6. Establishing settlements and industrial complexes away from the coastlines would help to protect them from damage due to sea level rise since they may be far enough away to avoid the rising sea level.
content_items: industrial complexes away from the coastlines would help to protect them from damage due to sea level rise since they may be far enough away to avoid the rising sea level.

section:

Answer BOTH questions in this section
objective: 7. Develop settlements and economic activities away from volcanic slopes.
content: 8. If residents and economic activities are located away from volcanoes, they would be less likely to incur damage and destruction. This would also save the lives of residents.
